newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices up, Calif deal ahead.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices up, Calif deal ahead.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond prices ended 1/8 to 1/4 point higher Monday as players awaited a $400 million Metropolitan Water District of Southern California deal expected to price via senior manager PaineWebber Inc on Tuesday.

"Mets are going to be priced it looks like tomorrow, so we have something to do this holiday-shortened week," one trader said, adding that the offering should do well. "(The deal) is a double-A stand alone probably coming insured so it will be a good bond. There will be a lot of interest in it."
Another market source said pricing is expected to be released shortly after 0900 EST Tuesday.
As for Monday's secondary market, the trader described it as "kind of a mixed bag."

"In the long end I bought stuff at the same level it traded Friday," he said. "The intermediate sector, I would say we are up about 1/8 (point), but that's really about it. We didn't really have a big up day here."
A municipal analyst said high-grade issues improved by two basis points in the intermediate range, while dollar bonds ended 1/8 to 1/4 point higher.
Activity was light, with bid lists totaling about $200 million. The lists contained "a lot of odd couponing and short calls," he said.
"There was a lot of stuff to bid on today," he said. "The the good news is at least a lot of it is trading."
In debt futures, the December municipal contract closed up 7/32 at 117-30/32. The December T-bond contract was up 5/32 at 115-15/32. The MOB spread was 79 ticks.
In the government market, the benchmark 30-year bond closed up 6/32 at 100-31/32 to yield 6.43 percent.

As for Monday's competitive sales, Hutchinson Shockey Erley & Co won the biggest deal, $30 million Unified School District No. 512, Kan., general obligation bonds. The firm won the bonds at a net interest cost of 5.195 percent.
